Federal Court
von Finckenstein, J.
November 9, 2005.
Counsel:
Shelley Levine, for the applicant;
Sally Thomas and John Pro, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Levine Associates, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant;
John H. Sims, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
von Finckenstein, J.
[orally]: This is an application for judicial review of the March 2, 2005 decision of the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (the "Board") where the Applicant was held to be neither a Convention Refugee nor a person in need of protection.

[2]
The Applicant, Wei Ting Xu, arrived in Canada on January 14, 2004, from the People's Republic of China (PRC). He claims that he began to practice Falun Gong in October 2002, knowing it had been illegal to do so in the PRC.

[3]
Prior to the hearing, the Board had advised the Applicant that identity would be an issue and had asked him to furnish his original Chinese Resident Identity Card (RIC), which he did. The Refugee protection officer examined the RIC and noted on a photocopy the words "Card (original) checked, OK. Returned to Cl [see footnote 1]". The Refugee protection officer then returned the original to the Applicant.

[4]
The Board denied his refugee claim finding inconsistencies and implausibilities regarding:
a) the claimant's mother's birthday
b) the Applicant's Hukou (a mandatory Chinese household registration passport)
c) the Applicant's work record.

[5]
The Board felt that the central issues in the claim were the claimant's identity and credibility of the alleged incidents. In light of the inconsistencies regarding the three items referred to, and in view of the documentary evidence establishing that "both counterfeit cards and fraudulently obtained but legitimately produced cards are obtainable and in circulation [see footnote 2]", the Board ruled that the RIC was fraudulent or fraudulently obtained.

[6]
There is no dispute between the parties that the appropriate standard of review for the assessment of identity documents is patent unreasonableness. ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .

[7]
During the hearing the Board never raised any concerns that it had with respect to the mother's birthday, the Hukou or the work record. It also did not raise the issue of the genuineness of the RIC.

[8]
It is trite law that in an IRP hearing, an applicant must be given an opportunity to explain contradictions. ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  para. 9). This Board clearly failed to do in this case.

[9]
In addition, the Board asked for the original of the RIC and received it. It did not forensically test the RIC and the Refugee Protection Officer noted "Card (original) checked, OK. Returned to Cl" on the photocopy thereof. The Board did not raise the genuineness of the RIC at the hearing but only observed elliptically "it says 'Okay. Returned to claimant'. It does not say whether the document is okay or not." [see footnote 3] Having never raised the genuineness of the RIC and not having tested it forensically, the Board then cannot assert the document is fraudulent or fraudulently obtained. There is no logical connection between the findings regarding the mother's birthday, the Hokou or the work record, and the genuineness of the RIC.

[10]
Accordingly, I find that the Board violated the rules of procedural fairness by not giving an opportunity to the Applicant to explain contradictions and made a patently unreasonable connection between the genuineness of the RIC and the contradiction regarding the Applicant's mother's birthday, his Hokou and his work record.

[11]
As a result, this application will succeed.
ORDER

[12]
THIS COURT ORDERS that the decision of the IRB dated March 2, 2005 is set aside and the matter be reconsidered by a differently constituted panel.
Footnotes
1. Tribunal record page 108. "Cl" stands for claimant
2. Tribunal Record page 12
3. Tribunal Record page 346
[End of document]

legal_issues: The standard of review applicable to assessments of identity documents in administrative proceedings.
Whether a failure to provide an opportunity to respond to alleged inconsistencies constitutes a denial of procedural fairness.
The requirements for establishing a connection between documentary evidence and findings of fact in administrative decision-making.
Whether a determination of fraudulence can be based on a lack of forensic testing of submitted documentation, absent prior notice of concerns regarding its authenticity.
The permissibility of drawing inferences regarding the authenticity of a document based on unrelated inconsistencies in an applicant's testimony.
factual_background: An individual, Wei Ting Xu, arrived in Canada on January 14, 2004, from the People's Republic of China (PRC).
The individual claims to have begun practicing Falun Gong in October 2002, despite its illegal status in the PRC.
Prior to a hearing, the Immigration and Refugee Board (the Board) requested and received the individual’s original Chinese Resident Identity Card (RIC).
A Refugee Protection Officer examined the RIC, noted it was checked and 'OK', and returned it to the individual.
The Board denied the individual’s refugee claim, citing inconsistencies and implausibilities regarding the individual’s mother’s birthday, Hukou (household registration passport), and work record.
The Board concluded the RIC was fraudulent or fraudulently obtained based on the identified inconsistencies and the general availability of fraudulent identity documents.
During the hearing, the Board did not raise concerns about the mother’s birthday, Hukou, work record, or the genuineness of the RIC.
The RIC was not subjected to forensic testing.

Applicants: The Board failed to give the applicant an opportunity to explain contradictions regarding his mother’s birthday, Hukou, and work record.

The Board made a patently unreasonable connection between the genuineness of the Resident Identity Card (RIC) and the inconsistencies regarding the applicant’s mother’s birthday, Hukou, and work record.
The Board did not raise concerns about the genuineness of the RIC during the hearing.
The Board did not forensically test the RIC, despite having received the original and a Refugee Protection Officer noting it was 'OK' upon examination.
The RIC was checked and returned to the applicant with a notation indicating it was 'OK'.
Respondents: The RIC was potentially fraudulent or fraudulently obtained, given the availability of counterfeit or fraudulently obtained cards in circulation.
Inconsistencies existed regarding the applicant’s mother’s birthday, Hukou, and work record.
Identity and the credibility of the alleged incidents were central issues in the claim.

court_analysis: The court found the Board’s decision to be procedurally unfair because the applicant was not given an opportunity to explain inconsistencies regarding his mother’s birthday, Hukou, and work record before the Board used those inconsistencies to question the authenticity of his Resident Identity Card (RIC). The court relied on established legal principle that applicants in immigration and refugee hearings must be given a chance to address contradictions.

The court determined the Board’s conclusion that the RIC was fraudulent or fraudulently obtained was patently unreasonable. The Board never explicitly raised concerns about the RIC’s genuineness during the hearing, despite having received and initially verified the original document (noted as “OK” by the Refugee Protection Officer).

The court found no logical connection between the inconsistencies in the applicant’s testimony regarding his mother’s birthday, Hukou, and work record, and the authenticity of the RIC. The Board’s reliance on the possibility of fraudulent cards in circulation, without any specific evidence regarding the applicant’s card, was deemed insufficient.

The court applied the standard of review of 'patent unreasonableness' to the Board’s assessment of the identity document, and concluded the Board’s reasoning fell below that standard due to the lack of opportunity for the applicant to respond and the absence of a logical link between the evidence and the conclusion.
final_outcome: The decision of the IRB dated March 2, 2005 is set aside.
The matter is to be reconsidered by a differently constituted panel.
